channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Listening Post: After Near Miss on Iran, Kerry Says Diplomacy Is Still the Right Path
item.description: As the prospect of a nuclear deal with Iran becomes more real, Secretary of State John Kerry is having to fend off those who want to pre-empt it — like Israel and Iran hawks in Congress.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry last week in Geneva, where negotiations ended without a deal on Iran’s disputed nuclear program.

item.title: The Lede: Aerial Views of Devastation in the Philippines
item.description: For the first time since Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, aerial views are showing the extent of the damage in some parts of the country, cut off because of downed communication lines.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: The Lede: Messages to and From Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan
item.description: With 10,000 people feared dead in the Tacloban area alone, people around the world are using online tools and social media to help find missing relatives and friends in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: People in Leyte, the Philippines, wrote messages on cardboard and torn-up paper plates to let loved ones know they were safe.

item.title: Mauritania Confronts Long Legacy of Slavery
item.description: Mauritania abolished slavery decades ago, but by some measures, it still has the highest prevalence of the practice in the world, and the government has created an agency to wipe out “vestiges” of the problem.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noura Mint Mourada, now 18, became a slave to a family in Boutilimit, Mauritania, at the age of 4.

item.title: News Analysis: Spying Scandal Alters U.S. Ties With Allies and Raises Talk of Policy Shift
item.description: Revelations about the N.S.A. surveillance efforts in Europe are resulting in unprecedented backlash, and some wonder if it is more important to collect data on allies or to be able to work with them.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Filipinos in U.S. Feel Helpless as They Try to Contact Kin
item.description: More than 300,000 Filipinos live in Southern California, and many were busy arranging relief aid as they waited for word from relatives in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By IAN LOVETT
item.media:description: Trinidad Limbaga, with her daughter Teri Red in Los Angeles, said she was unable to reach her sister in the Philippines.

item.title: Typhoon in Philippines Casts Long Shadow Over U.N. Talks on Climate Treaty
item.description: In Warsaw, delegates suggested that a warming planet had turned Typhoon Haiyan, considered one of the strongest storms to make landfall on record, into a lethal monster.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN and JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: U.N. Relief Official to Help Coordinate Aid Efforts
item.description: Valerie Amos sought to take charge of the relief efforts in the Philippines as governments mobilized to rush supplies to the victims of the storm.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Valerie Amos, the United Nations under secretary general for humanitarian affairs, was expected to arrive in the Philippines on Tuesday. She released $25 million from a special fund to help pay for immediate assistance.

item.title: Struggle for Survival in Philippine City Shattered by Typhoon
item.description: Destroyed buildings lined every road of Tacloban, the city hit hardest by the typhoon, and many streets were still so clogged with debris that they were barely discernible.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Uprooted coconut trees near Guiuan in the Philippines, which was devastated by Typhoon Haiyan’s winds and storm surge.

item.title: Bloody End for Iranian Rockers Seeking Musical Freedom in U.S.
item.description: The gunman also killed himself, the police said. Two of his victims were in a rock band called the Yellow Dogs, made up of other Iranian expatriates.
item.dc:creator: By VIVIAN YEE and J. DAVID GOODMAN
item.media:description: The Yellow Dogs, from left, Arash and Soroush Farazmand, killed on Monday, and Siavash Karampour and Koory Mirz.

item.title: Lawyer for Ukraine Opposition Leader Is Questioned
item.description: The chief defense lawyer for the imprisoned opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko was questioned on suspicion that he had beaten his former wife.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: In Challenge, Former Rebels in Libya Form Own Oil Company
item.description: The rebels’ establishment of a regional oil company to sell crude from oil fields and port terminals they occupy was seen as a symbolic move, but it was another escalation of tensions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Greenpeace Detainees Are Transferred
item.description: Russia’s prison authorities began transferring 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship from Murmansk to St. Petersburg on Monday.
item.category: International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Four Are Sentenced for Airport Attack
item.description: A Moscow court on Monday sentenced three men to life in prison and a fourth man to 10 years for their role in the 2011 suicide bombing at the Domodedovo airport.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: MERS Virus Found in Patient’s Pet Camel
item.description: The discovery of the virus that causes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in a camel belonging to a recent human victim adds credence to the theory that the virus originates in bats but can reach humans through camels.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Cyclone Kills at Least 100
item.description: Hundreds of people have also been reported missing since a tropical cyclone hit Somalia’s semiautonomous Puntland region over the weekend, the government said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Lede: How to Help Typhoon Victims in the Philippines
item.description: A list of contact information for some organizations that plan to provide relief to victims of Typhoon Haiyan.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Vilnius Journal: Silent Sentinels at Center of Lithuanian Debate on Bygone Era
item.description: In the capital, Vilnius, statues that trumpet Communism, an ideology rejected by Lithuania more than two decades ago, have drawn anger, but some see a value in preserving them.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Alnis Stakle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Green Bridge over the Neris River in Vilnius, Lithuania, features statues of Red Army soldiers. The city is wrestling with whether to use public money to restore the works.

item.title: Leading Syrian Opposition Group, Yielding to Pressure, Votes to Join Peace Talks
item.description: A statement from the main rebel coalition appeared to drop a demand that President Bashar al-Assad step down before negotiations could begin.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s Foreign Minister Subtweets Kerry
item.description: After Secretary of State John Kerry insisted that it was unfair to blame his French counterpart for scuttling a deal on the Iranian nuclear program, Iran’s chief negotiator, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, pushed back on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A New Political Party Aims to Save Socialism, and the Constitution, in China
item.description: Wang Zheng has chosen Bo Xilai, the fallen politician who is now serving a life sentence for corruption and abuse of power, as the party’s chairman.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Wang Zheng, a founder of the party, which has named the imprisoned politician Bo Xilai as its chairman.

item.title: Germany to Form Task Force on Looted Art
item.description: German authorities are reacting to calls to release information quickly about paintings, many looted, that were discovered in Munich.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA COHEN and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: “Riders on the Beach” by Max Liebermann, now rediscovered.

item.title: Militant Leader Is Killed in Pakistan
item.description: Nasiruddin Haqqani, the group’s main financier, was shot dead outside Islamabad in the latest setback for terrorist groups sheltering in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD
item.media:description: Children gathered on Monday at the spot where Nasiruddin Haqqani was said to have been killed on the outskirts of Islamabad.

item.title: China’s One-Day Shopping Spree Sets Record in Online Sales
item.description: Chinese consumers were taking to the Internet in record numbers for an annual 24-hour online sale that has ballooned into the world’s biggest e-commerce event.
item.dc:creator: By SHANSHAN WANG and ERIC PFANNER

item.title: The Lede: Eyewitness Reports After Typhoon in Philippines
item.description: Video and photos show the extent of the damage after powerful Typhoon Haiyan tore through the center of the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
